Fig. 1 XRD patterns of: (a) Al-1, Mo/Al-1 and the reduced Mo/Al-1; (b) Al-2, Mo/Al-2 and the reduced Mo/Al-2; (c) Al-3, Mo/Al-3 and the reduced Mo/Al-3; (b) Al-4, Mo/Al-4 and the reduced Mo/Al-4. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of Al2O3 products and the corresponding catalysts: (a) Al-1, (b) Al-2, (c) Al-3, (d) Al-4, (a’) Mo/Al-1, (b’) Mo/Al-2, (c’) Mo/Al-3, (d’) Mo/Al-4. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and (b) pore size distribution curves of Mo/Al-X catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR profiles of Mo/Al-X. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS of Mo 3d region of the reduced catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of the reduced catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TEM images of the reduced catalysts: (a–c) Mo/Al-1, (d–f) Mo/Al-2, (g–i) Mo/Al-3 and (j–l) Mo/Al-4. Table 7 Reaction time Catalyst Binding energy (eV) Peak area ratio Mo6+ Mo4+ Mo4+/Mo6+ 100 min Mo/Al-1 232.9 231.7 0.39 Mo/Al-4 233.0 231.7 0.15 365 min Mo/Al-1 233.1 231.7 0.45 Mo/Al-4 232.9 231.9 0.17 Molybdenum-based catalysts supported on alumina for direct dehydrogenation of isobutane Jiameng Wang 1 Zhen Song 1 Mingxun Han Xiangxiang Li Lihong Zhang ⁎ Department of Catalysis Science and Technology and Tianjin Key Laboratory of Applied Catalysis Science & Technology, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, PR China Department of Catalysis Science and Technology and Tianjin Key Laboratory of Applied Catalysis Science & Technology School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 PR China Department of Catalysis Science and Technology and Tianjin Key Laboratory of Applied Catalysis Science & Technology, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work A series of Al2O3 supported Mo-based Mo/Al-X (X = 1, 2, 3, 4) catalysts were prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation method. The Mo/Al-X catalysts were evaluated in the isobutane direct dehydrogenation reaction at 600 °C, and the physicochemical properties of Mo/Al-X catalysts were investigated by using XRD, BET, SEM, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, TEM, XPS and TG-DTG techniques. The results indicated that the MoOx species were highly dispersed, and Mo4+ ions were the main active species for the reaction of isobutane direct dehydrogenation to isobutene. The Mo/Al-1 catalyst displayed the hollow microspheric structure with mesoporous shell and big pore window. And Mo/Al-1 catalyst with the lowest S BET value of 167 m2•g−1 exhibited optimal catalytic performance, achieving superior and stable isobutane conversion of 30.5% and isobutene selectivity of 84.6%, respectively. Excellent catalytic performance, anti-sintering and carbon-resistance ability of Mo/Al-1 catalyst are attributed to the low specific surface area, small particle size, high Mo4+/Mo6+ molar ratio, strong Mo species and support interaction, and high concentration and strength of weak and medium-strong acid sites. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Isobutane dehydrogenation Mo-based catalyst Interaction Surface acidity Carbon-resistance 1 Introduction Isobutene is a significant intermediate for producing industrial products [1]. However, the isobutene production by traditional ways cannot provide sufficient isobutene to satisfy the increasing market demand [2]. In recent years, the production process of isobutene from isobutane direct dehydrogenation has attracted widespread attention from researchers and providing a cost-effective production path [3,4]. In addition, the maturity of shale gas mining technology has lowered the price of low-carbon alkanes and created good conditions for isobutane dehydrogenation to produce isobutene [5]. Currently, Pt- and CrOx-based catalysts have been applied in the industrial process of low-carbon alkanes dehydrogenation [6–9]. Although CrOx-based catalysts show good dehydrogenation performance, its toxicity could not be avoided. For Pt-based catalysts, a lot of research has been done, including adding promoters, optimizing support materials and so on [10,11]. However, Pt-based catalysts still suffer from problems such as high production costs and deactivation by carbon deposition and metal sintering. These issues make it necessary to explore alternative catalysts that show environmental and economic advantages. Recently, other non-noble metal-based catalysts have been widely studied such as Zn [12,13], Fe [14,15], Ni [16–18], Zr [19], Ga [20,21], V [22,23] etc. MoOx as a transition metal oxide is relatively affordable and nontoxic to the environment, and can be considered for using in isobutane direct dehydrogenation systems. As a candidate for catalytic isobutane direct dehydrogenation, the studies on Mo-based catalysts have made some progress, although the supported Mo-based catalysts have been intensively employed in oxidative dehydrogenation [24–26]. Wang et al. had studied the performance of isobutane direct dehydrogenation over different supports loaded Mo-based catalysts, and declared that Mo4+ ions may be the actual active species for catalytic isobutane dehydrogenation [27]. And the ordered mesoporous molybdenum aluminum catalyst with strong metal-support interaction exhibited better stability and coking resistance than that of the disordered one [28]. In addition, a feasible method for developing high-efficiency non-noble metal dehydrogenation catalysts based on Mo-C T hybrid nanowires calcined at different temperatures has also been applied in the isobutane direct dehydrogenation [29]. For the dehydrogenation reaction, a catalyst support is crucial to optimizing the catalytic performance by adjusting the electronic and geometric structure of the active metal phase [30]. And Al2O3 is considered as an excellent support for Mo-based catalysts because it is easy to control the surface area and pore-size distribution [31]. In this work, three Al2O3 with different texture were prepared by different method as the supports of Mo-based catalysts. The object is to study the relationship between the catalyst properties and the catalytic behaviors of supported Mo-based catalysts for isobutane direct dehydrogenation reaction. For comparison, the commercial unordered mesoporous Al2O3 supported Mo-based catalyst was also synthesized and evaluated. The evolution of the physicochemical properties of the different catalyst during different stages were characterized, and properties-activity relationships of prepared catalysts were analyzed and elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Materials The analytical grade chemicals include KAl(SO4)2•12H2O, Al(NO3)3•9H2O, CO(NH2)2, γ-Al2O3, C2H5OH, pseudo-boehmite and (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O. KAl(SO4)2•12H2O, Al(NO3)3•9H2O, CO(NH2)2 and C2H5OH were purchased from Tianjin Yuanli Chemical Co., Ltd, γ-Al2O3 was purchased from Aladdin Industrial corporation, pseudo-boehmite was provided by CenerTech Tianjin Chemical Research and Design Institute Co., Ltd, and (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O was purchased from Shanghai Dibo Biological Technology Co., Ltd. 2.1.2 Alumina preparation The alumina was prepared by previously reported method [32,33]. KAl(SO4)2•12H2O and CO(NH2)2 were dissolved in 70 mL deionized water at a molar ratio of 1: 2, and vigorous stirred at room temperature. Then the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 3 h. After thorough washing with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, the products were dried at 80 °C overnight and then calcined at 600 °C in a muffle for 3 h. The final product was named as Al-1. It was prepared according to the procedures reported in the literature [34]. 3.75 g of Al(NO3)3•9H2O and 5.41 g of CO(NH2)2 were dissolved in 65 mL deionized water. After thorough stirring, the solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 24 h. Then, washed and dried at 80 °C. The obtained solid was calcined at 600 °C for 3 h and marked as Al-2. We also used pseudo-boehmite as the aluminum source, and the calcination process was the same as that for Al-1 and Al-2. The corresponding sample was labelled as Al-3. For comparison, the commercial unordered mesoporous Al2O3 was purchased from Aladdin Industrial corporation and denoted as Al-4. 2.1.3 Catalyst preparation Using (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O as the Mo-based precursor, the MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the incipient impregnation method, and theoretical amounts of Mo was 2 wt%. First, the Al2O3 support was impregnated in the aqueous solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O at room temperature for 24 h. Next, the samples were dried at 120 °C for 12 h and later calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The samples were denoted as Mo/Al-X (X = 1, 2, 3, 4). We measured the content of Mo in the catalyst by ICP-OES, as shown in Table 1 , and the content of Mo is not much different from the theoretical value. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was measured on D8-Foucas (Bruker), with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out on MAIA3 TESCAN to observe the morphology of the Al2O3 samples and catalysts. N2 adsorption-desorption was performed to collect the textural properties on an automatic analyzer (QUA211007, Quantachrome, USA). The elemental composition of catalysts were measured on Agilent 725 by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on automatic multipurpose adsorption apparatus (tp5080 XQINSTRUMENT CO., LTD China) to characterize the reduction ability of the catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out to test the surface elements chemical states of the reduced and spent catalysts on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi (US) using Al Kα radiation. The NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements were carried out on Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 apparatus. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on JEM-2100 field-emission transmission electron microscope. The TG-DTG measurements were utilized to determine the carbon on the spent catalysts by HITACHI STA7300 thermal gravimetric analyzer. 2.3 Catalytic performance test The test was conducted in the fixed-bed reactor at 600 °C under atmospheric pressure with 0.5 g of the catalyst (40–60 mesh). The catalyst was reduced in 5vol% H2/N2 (30 mL min−1) at 600 °C for 2 h before the reaction. And then, introducing isobutane and hydrogen (the molar ratio of iC4H10: H2 = 1: 1) into the reactor, and the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of isobutane was 3 h−1. The gas compositions were analyzed by gas chromatography with a FID detector. Isobutane conversion, isobutene selectivity and isobutene yield were calculated as follows: i C 4 H 10 Conversion ( % ) = i C 4 H 10 in − i C 4 H 10 out i C 4 H 10 in × 100 i C 4 H 8 Selectivity ( % ) = i C 4 H 8 out i C 4 H 10 in − i C 4 H 10 out × 100 i C 4 H 8 Yield ( % ) = Conversion × Selectivity × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Texture and structure of Mo/Al-X catalysts 3.1.1 XRD Fig. 1 presents the XRD patterns of the different Al2O3 supports, Mo/Al-X (X = 1, 2, 3, 4) catalysts as well as the reduced Mo/Al-X catalysts. The diffraction peaks of the synthesized Al2O3 supports are same with commercial Al2O3 (Al-4) presented at 2θ = 31.9° (220), 37.3° (311), 39.5° (222), 45.7° (400), 60.9° (511) and 67.0° (440), which can be assigned to the single γ-Al2O3 crystalline phase (JCPDF file No. 10–0425). The diffraction peaks of Al-1 are very narrow and sharp when compared to other supports, indicating the Al-1 has high crystallinity of γ-Al2O3 phase. For Mo/Al-X catalysts, the absence of diffraction peaks corresponding to Mo species, such as MoO3 phase, indicates that Mo species should be assembled in small size or distributed on the surface of γ-Al2O3 support in highly dispersed amorphous state. After reduction, the diffraction peak of Mo species were also not observed in the XRD patterns. This implies that the dispersed state and particle size of the Mo species can be kept stable during the high temperature treatment. 3.1.2 SEM The SEM images of Al2O3 supports, as well as Mo/Al-X catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . It can be seen that Al-1 displays hollow microsphere with well-defined hollow core, porous shell and a big pore window structure. From viewpoint of the cross-section of shell, it reveals that the shells are composed of the thin nanosheets. And the size of a single microsphere is about 6 μm. The Al-2 is formed in rod-shaped particles with a little rough surface and a diameter of 400 nm or less. For Al-3, the block particles with abundant hierarchical pores can be found, and there are small flake structures on the surface. Further, it clearly depicts that the commercial Al-4 support is constructed by small block particles, which is the aggregated Al2O3 nanoparticles. The similar morphologies can be seen in the corresponding Mo/Al-X catalysts. 3.1.3 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms It can be observed that all the catalysts present typical mesoporous feature with IV isotherms in Fig. 3 (a). A typical H3-type hysteresis loop can be observed for Mo/Al-3 catalyst, whereas the other samples display a small and irregular H4-type hysteresis loops. The H3-type hysteresis loops are related to the slit-shaped pores due to the aggregates of plate-like particles. And type H4 loop is corresponding to narrow slit-like pores. The strong hysteresis loop Mo/Al-3 catalyst is related to the high adsorbed N2vol, which illustrates the increase of the pore volume depending on the textural characteristics of supports. In agreement with the hysteresis loop features, the pore size distributions are mainly concentrated in the middle pore range for all catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3(b). This further confirms the mesoporous characteristics of the Mo/Al-X. Moreover, the pore diameter distribution of Mo/Al-1 catalyst is narrow and mainly located in small size range, which indicates these small pores are compactly and uniformly distributed on the shell. The double-peak distribution of Mo/Al-2 catalyst should be associated with the rod-shaped Al2O3 supported Mo-based oxides with two different pore size branches. The similar pore size distribution range can be found in Mo/Al-4 catalyst with small block particles. However, the pore size distribution of Mo/Al-3 catalyst with a rather wide range and a relatively big value has been obtained, arising from hierarchical pores. As shown in Table 2 , these differences are in good accordance with their different textural properties. The lowest S BET value of 167 m2•g−1 is possessed by Mo/Al-1 catalyst, which is similar to 184 m2•g−1 of Mo/Al-4 catalyst. The Mo/Al-3 catalyst exhibits a large S BET value of 365 m2•g−1, high V P value of 1.37 cm3•g−1 and D P value of 9.6 nm. And a middle S BET value of 258 m2•g−1 can be found for Mo/Al-2 catalyst. The big D P and S BET values for Mo/Al-3 catalyst are related to the abundant hierarchical pores, while the low D P and S BET values for Mo/Al-1 catalyst should be associated to the short mesochannels in the porous shell of hollow microsphere (see Fig. 2). The low-temperature N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of Al2O3 products are shown in Fig. S1. And the textural properties of the supports are also listed in Table 2. After impregnating Mo species, the most probable pore size was well maintained for Al-1. However, the specific surface areas and pore volumes of the catalysts slightly reduced when compared to the corresponding support. 3.1.4 H2-TPR In Fig. 4 , H2-TPR profiles are performed to determine the reducibility of the as-prepared Mo/Al-X. In any case, it is easy to distinguish two H2 consumption processes from each H2-TPR profile, although the high temperature peaks have not yet appeared completely. The lower temperature peak is related to Mo6+ species reduce to Mo4+ species [35,36]. And the peak at the relatively higher temperature can be assigned to the reduction of Mo4+species to low valence Mo species [35,36]. As for the high temperature reduction peak, it can be noted that the initial reduction stage shift from ca. 750 °C of Mo/Al-2, Mo/Al-3 and Mo/Al-4 to above 890 °C of Mo/Al-1. It suggests that it is difficult to reduce from Mo4+species to low valence Mo species for Mo/Al-1. At the same time, the peaks at low temperature also tend to increase the reduction temperature from Mo/Al-4 (518 °C) to Mo/Al-3 (542 °C) to Mo/Al-2 (560 °C) and to Mo/Al-1 (635 °C). The higher the reduction temperature of the catalyst, the stronger the interaction between Mo species and Al2O3 support. The values of H2 consumption in the reduction process are shown in Table 3 . Among samples, the sample Mo/Al-1 shows the highest H2 consumption. In fact, there are no difference about the Mo loading among these catalysts, which was measured by ICP-OES. Therefore it can be speculated that the Mo6+ species on the surface of Mo/Al-1 can be easily reduced into Mo4+species. In fact, all catalysts were reduced at 600 °C for 2 h in 5vol% H2/N2 before dehydrogenation reaction. So it can be determined that the Mo4+ species should be the only reduced species. 3.1.5 XPS Fig. 5 shows the Mo 3d region spectra for the reduced catalysts, and Table 4 lists the XPS characteristics. As shown in Fig. 5, the Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 region can be deconvoluted into two peaks, respectively. The binding energy (BE) value of each peak can be used to determine the oxidation state of Mo element in the catalysts. The peak with BE of around 233.0 eV should belong to Mo6+ species, and peaks appeared at BE of about 231.0 eV can be attributed to Mo4+species [29]. The coexistence of two Mo species indicates the Mo6+ species only can be partially reduced to Mo4+ species under the reduction condition. Compared with MoO3 with BE of 231.7 eV [37], the Al2O3 supported Mo-based catalysts give a high BE value for Mo6+ species, which can be explained by the interaction between Mo species and Al2O3. It is reported that higher BE corresponds to the stronger Mo species and support interaction [38,39]. The Mo/Al-1 has a larger BE compared to the other three catalysts, so the Mo/Al-1 has stronger Mo species and support interaction. Also, the high BE value means the Mo/Al-1 catalyst has a superior Mo dispersion [40]. As reported in Table 4, it can be found that the peak area ratio of Mo4+/Mo6+ increases in the order of Mo/Al-4, Mo/Al-2, Mo/Al-3 and Mo/Al-1. It can be inferred that Mo/Al-1 has more Mo4+ species. 3.1.6 NH3-TPD The NH3-TPD profiles of the reduced catalysts could be fitted into three peaks, as shown in Fig. 6 . The relative concentration and strength of acidic sites could be calculated and classified according to the peak area fraction and peak temperature (T max) respectively, and Table 5 presents the results. About the NH3-TPD profiles of the reduced catalysts, the first peak appeared at low temperature should be assigned to weak acid sites (peak I), and second much broader peak should be related to medium-strong acid sites (peak II), the additional peak appeared at high temperature corresponds to strong acid sites (peak III) [28]. In the reduced Mo/Al-1, Mo/Al-2 and Mo/Al-3, the acid concentration is nearly similar between the weak and strong acid sites. However, the strong acid concentration is three times larger than the weak one in the reduced Mo/Al-4. Further compared, the reduced Mo/Al-1 shows a slightly lower concentration of strong acid sites, and the NH3 desorption from weak and middle-strong acid sites takes place at a higher temperature. It is known that the side reactions are easily occurred over the strong acid sites during the isobutane dehydrogenation process, such as polymerization, isomerization and cracking. In other words, the more and stronger weak and middle-strong acid sites are more favorable for the dehydrogenation reaction [12,41–45]. That is to say, the low concentration and strength of strong acid sites on the reduced Mo/Al-1 surface can minimize and inhibit the side reactions and further carbon formation. It can be deduced that the reduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst will present excellent isobutane dehydrogenation performance toward isobutene and anti-carbon ability. 3.1.7 TEM Fig. 7 shows the particle size distribution (PSD), TEM and HR-TEM images of the reduced catalysts. It can be seen from the TEM images that the flake-shaped structure of Mo/Al-1 catalyst are consistent with the flake-shaped morphology arranged on the shell like shown in Fig. 2, and Mo/Al-2 exhibits a closely arranged rod-like structure, small flake structures of Mo/Al-3 and small block particles of Mo/Al-4 can also be observed. The HR-TEM images of all samples present 0.34 nm lattice spacing, and it is assigned to the (011) planes of MoO2. This confirms the formation of Mo4+species on the surface of the reduced catalysts, and it is good agreement with the XPS results. The PSD illustrates that the average particle size of particles increases from Mo/Al-1 (1.0 nm) to Mo/Al-2 (1.8 nm) to Mo/Al-4 (2.8 nm) and to Mo/Al-3 (4.0 nm). Besides the smallest particle size, the PSD range of Mo/Al-1 is also the narrowest among the reduced catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic activity After isobutane dehydrogenation reaction, the isobutane conversion, isobutene selectivity, isobutene yield and by-product selectivity of various reduced Mo/Al-X catalysts are displayed in Fig. 8 . An activity test was carried out on the unreduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst, and the compared results are included in Fig. S2. It shows that reduced catalyst has better dehydrogenation activity. The isobutane conversion and isobutene selectivity of the reduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst are higher than that of unreduced one. Besides, the stability of Mo/Al-1 catalyst is also improved after reduction. Based on the analysis about H2-TPR and XPS result mentioned above, it is reasonable to deduce that the pre-reduction treatment is helpful to form Mo4+species. The variation of the conversion and selectivity of the unreduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst should be arising from the continuous reduction of Mo6+species into Mo4+species in the reductive feed gas. Accordingly, the formation of surface Mo4+species should be essential for the dehydrogenation reaction. This is consistent with the statement reported by Wang et al. [27]. Compared with the Mo/Al-4 in Fig. 8(a), other three catalysts exhibit higher activity. The reduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst exhibits distinctive catalytic performance. Its isobutane conversion gradually increases to 30.5% and then remains stable. It is seen that reduced Mo/Al-2 catalyst gives an optimal initial isobutane conversion of 43.5%, but the conversion slightly decreases to 27.5% after 365 min of reaction. During the same period, the isobutane conversion of reduced Mo/Al-3 catalyst drops from initial 32.6% to 24.6%, with an optimal conversion of 35.2% after 35 min of the reaction. The trend of isobutane conversion of Mo/Al-4 catalyst is nearly similar to reduced Mo/Al-3 catalyst, it increases from 29.6% during the initial 35 min and then decreases to 20.8% after reaching the highest conversion of 32.7%. In any case, the reduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst finally obtained the most stable and highest conversion. The most essential cause is attributed to the high content of Mo4+species on the surface of the reduced Mo/Al-1. In addition, the special hollow microsphere structure with big cavity and nanosheets constructed porous shell is in favor of diffusion of reactant and product molecules, and also utilization of active sites on the surface [46]. Furthermore, the small particle size of Mo species is also beneficial to the accessibility of the reactants. The reduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst exhibits the most stable and highest isobutene selectivity of around 84.6%. And the selectivity of other catalysts are quite similar to each other and show an increasing tendency from 44.5 to 67.1%. The lowest selectivity of isobutene is exhibited by the reduced Mo/Al-3. Additionally, from Fig. 8(d), it can be seen that the low selectivity of by-products, including CH4, C2H6, C2H4, C3H8 and C3H6, can be obtained on the reduced Mo/Al-1. However, the other three catalysts have more cracking products. The prominent isobutene selectivity of the reduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst can be assigned to its low S BET value, which is beneficial for isobutene desorption, and then reduces the possibility of deep dehydrogenation and hydrogenolysis at the active sites [47]. And the high concentration and strength of the weak and middle-strong acid sites of the reduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst also can improve the isobutene selectivity and prevent side reactions and carbon formation [48]. Moreover, the small and highly dispersed active species are also effective for selective activation of CH bonds and suppressing the side reactions over Mo/Al-1 catalyst in the isobutane dehydrogenation reaction. The superior stability of Mo/Al-1 catalyst is related to the strong interaction between Mo species and support, which can resist the aggregation of active Mo species during the reaction. In general, Mo/Al-1 catalyst showed the highest isobutene yield, as shown in Fig. 8(c). Moreover, the comparison of isobutane dehydrogenation performance between the Mo/Al-1 in this work and previously reported Mo-based catalysts were listed in Table 6 . And the reduced Mo/Al-1 catalyst shows relatively high conversion and selectivity, and is a promising catalyst with excellent performance. 3.3 Characterization of the used Mo/Al-X catalysts 3.3.1 TG-DTG Carbon deposition behavior on the used Mo/Al-X can be determined by TG-DTG experiments. From Fig. 9 , the used Mo/Al-1 catalyst shows the lowest amount of carbon deposit compared to other three catalysts. A higher amount of carbon deposit can be obtained by the used Mo/Al-3 and Mo/Al-4. The used Mo/Al-2 catalyst has a severe carbon deposition and its amount is nearly 7 times larger than that of Mo/Al-1. The DTG curve of the used Mo/Al-2, Mo/Al-3 and Mo/Al-4 shows two carbon combustion peaks, the low temperature peak belongs to amorphous carbon, and the peak at high temperature belongs to graphitized carbon [49]. However, Mo/Al-1 catalyst has only one peak at low temperature. It indicates that the other three catalysts are more likely to form graphitized carbon than Mo/Al-1 catalyst, which is not conducive to regeneration treatment. And the low carbon deposit is an important factor of outstanding performance of Mo/Al-1. 3.3.2 SEM As shown in Fig. 10 , the morphology of the used catalysts has not changed much after the activity test. The used Mo/Al-1 catalyst still maintains hollow microsphere structure, while some of the nanosheets structure on the surface is partially destroyed. The rod-shape structure also can be found on used Mo/Al-2 catalyst. The used Mo/Al-3 and Mo/Al-4 catalysts still display block particles. It is clearly that a large amount of carbon fibers and particles can be found on the surface of the used Mo/Al-2, Mo/Al-3 and Mo/Al-4, which is consistent with the TG-DTG result. 3.3.3 XRD After the isobutene dehydrogenation reaction, the XRD patterns of used catalysts are shown in Fig. 11 . Compared with the fresh catalysts, the diffraction peaks of the Al2O3 phase (JCPDF file No. 10–0425) on the used catalysts have negligible change. In addition, the new diffraction peak can be detected at 2θ of 26.2° for the used catalysts except the used Mo/Al-1 catalyst, which belong to the carbon deposits (JCPDF file No. 75–1621). 3.3.4 TEM From the TEM image of the used Mo/Al-1 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 12, it can be seen that the nanosheets structure has been kept well. The MoO2 (011) planes can be found on all used catalysts. It indicates that the Mo4+ species still exist during reaction. After reaction, the average particle size of Mo/Al-2, Mo/Al-3 and Mo/Al-4 catalysts have increased from 1.8 nm, 4.0 nm and 2.8 nm to 2.6 nm, 5.1 nm and 3.5 nm. However, under the same condition, the size of Mo species on the used Mo/Al-1 catalyst remains unchanged and most of Mo species are still highly dispersed after reaction. This indicates that the Mo/Al-1 catalyst has stronger Mo-support interaction and can avoid the active Mo species sintering. This also explains why Mo/Al-1 catalyst has excellent isobutene selectivity and low by-product selectivity. 3.3.5 XPS The XPS technique was applied to probe the surface chemical states of Mo on the surface of the used samples. XPS spectra of the Mo 3d region for the used catalysts are shown in Fig. 13 and their corresponding XPS characteristics are listed in Table 7 . For concision, only the Mo 3d5/2 region is analyzed in detail. The valence state of surface Mo species on the used catalysts is the same as that of the reduced catalysts. This indicates that there is still no new Mo species formation during reaction, such as metallic Mo species. This further suggests that the dehydrogenation reaction is indeed catalyzed by the MoOx species. The difference is that the Mo4+/Mo6+ ratios in catalysts have an increase trend, indicating that the reduction of Mo4+ species gradually proceeds with increasing reaction time. After reaction of 100 min, the ratio of Mo4+/Mo6+ of Mo/Al-1 increases from 0.26 of fresh catalyst to 0.39 of used one, and further increases to 0.45 after reaction of 365 min. It means that the increase degree of Mo4+/Mo6+ ratio becomes smaller with reaction time, and that explains why the dehydrogenation is getting better at the beginning of the reaction. It also can be found that the Mo4+/Mo6+ ratio of Mo/Al-4 is still lower than that of Mo/Al-1. It can be attributed to the stronger reducibility of Mo/Al-1 than that of Mo/Al-4 as mentioned in H2-TPR result. 4 Conclusions Several Al2O3 supported Mo-based Mo/Al-X (X = 1, 2, 3, 4) catalysts were successfully prepared and applied in the isobutene direct dehydrogenation process to investigate their catalytic performance. The reduced Mo/Al-1 exhibited good performance and prominent resistance to carbon deposition for the isobutane dehydrogenation. The high selectivity and outstanding anti-carbon deposition capability are arising from the high concentration and strength of weak and medium-strong acid sites. In addition, the superior stability can be attributed to the strong Mo species and support interaction, which is beneficial to disperse the active Mo4+species and maintain the small particle size during reaction. This Mo-based catalyst is expected to be a promising non-noble metal catalyst for the dehydrogenation of low-carbon alkanes. Declaration of Competing Interest There are no conflicts to declare. coredata.dc:description: A series of Al2O3 supported Mo-based Mo/Al-X (X = 1, 2, 3, 4) catalysts were prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation method. The Mo/Al-X catalysts were evaluated in the isobutane direct dehydrogenation reaction at 600 °C, and the physicochemical properties of Mo/Al-X catalysts were investigated by using XRD, BET, SEM, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, TEM, XPS and TG-DTG techniques. The results indicated that the MoOx species were highly dispersed, and Mo4+ ions were the main active species for the reaction of isobutane direct dehydrogenation to isobutene. The Mo/Al-1 catalyst displayed the hollow microspheric structure with mesoporous shell and big pore window. And Mo/Al-1 catalyst with the lowest S BET value of 167 m2•g−1 exhibited optimal catalytic performance, achieving superior and stable isobutane conversion of 30.5% and isobutene selectivity of 84.6%, respectively. Excellent catalytic performance, anti-sintering and carbon-resistance ability of Mo/Al-1 catalyst are attributed to the low specific surface area, small particle size, high Mo4+/Mo6+ molar ratio, strong Mo species and support interaction, and high concentration and strength of weak and medium-strong acid sites.
coredata.dc:title: Molybdenum-based catalysts supported on alumina for direct dehydrogenation of isobutane
